title: Arnold Umbach
text:
Arnold William Umbach Jr. (December 6, 1942 – May 30, 2020) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who appeared in parts of two seasons in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> for the <a href="1964%20Milwaukee%20Braves%20season">1964 Milwaukee Braves</a> and the <a href="1966%20Atlanta%20Braves%20season">1966 Atlanta Braves</a>. A <a href="right-handed">right-hander</a> whose pro career extended from 1961 through 1968, he was listed as tall and .
Umbach was born in <a href="Williamsburg%2C%20Virginia">Williamsburg, Virginia</a>, but grew up in <a href="Auburn%2C%20Alabama">Auburn, Alabama</a>; he graduated from <a href="Tennessee">Tennessee</a>'s <a href="Baylor%20School">Baylor School</a>, then later returned to his home city to earn a degree from <a href="Auburn%20University">Auburn University</a>. Fresh off his schoolboy career, he signed a $100,000 bonus contract with the Braves in June 1961. After four seasons in the club's <a href="farm%20system">farm system</a>, he was called up to Milwaukee in September 1964 and given a <a href="starting%20pitcher">start</a> in the club's next-to-last game of the season, October 3 against the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> at <a href="Milwaukee%20County%20Stadium">County Stadium</a>. He went 8 <a href="innings%20pitched">innings</a> and departed with an 11–3 lead after surrendering 11 <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> and four <a href="bases%20on%20balls">bases on balls</a>. Two <a href="earned%20run">unearned runs</a> would score off Umbach's successor on the mound, <a href="Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Baseball Hall of Fame</a> <a href="left-handed">southpaw</a> <a href="Warren%20Spahn">Warren Spahn</a> (in Spahn's 714th and final appearance in a Brave uniform), but Umbach secured the victory in his <a href="MLB">MLB</a> debut. After spending 1965 at <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a>, Umbach worked in 22 games during 1966, the Braves' first year in <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>, losing his only two <a href="decision%20%28baseball%29">decisions</a> but posting a solid 3.10 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a>. Of his 22 appearances, three were starts, and on June 4, he held the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a> to seven hits and one unearned run, again going 8 innings. But he departed the game with the score tied at one, and his reliever, veteran <a href="Ted%20Abernathy">Ted Abernathy</a>, got credit for the victory when Atlanta broke through with the winning tally in the home half of the ninth.
Umbach appeared in 23 MLB games, and fashioned a 1–2 <a href="win%E2%80%93loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">won–lost record</a>. He permitted 51 hits and 22 bases on balls in 49 career innings pitched, with 30 <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a>s. After the 1966 season, he was included in a blockbuster trade that sent longtime Braves star <a href="Eddie%20Mathews">Eddie Mathews</a>, also a future Hall of Famer, to the <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Astros</a>. But Umbach never appeared in a Houston uniform and retired after only two <a href="Double-A%20%28baseball%29">Double-A</a> appearances in 1968. 
In addition to Auburn University, Umbach attended law school at the <a href="University%20of%20Alabama%20School%20of%20Law">University of Alabama</a> and <a href="Emory%20University%20School%20of%20Law">Emory University</a> and after his pitching career ended he was a practicing attorney in his home city of Auburn. He died at his home there on May 30, 2020, due to complications from <a href="Parkinson%27s%20disease">Parkinson's disease</a>.
